author: @chahineatallah2636
text: i liked this video, very informative, so after watching all the python beginners, i wrote something like that ,also utilizing function def bmi(w,h):     b=(w*703)/(h**2)     return b weight=float(input("Enter your weight in pounds")) height=float(input("Enter your height in inches")) yourbmi=bmi(weight,height) print("your bmi is:") print(round(yourbmi,2))  if yourbmi<18.5:     print("you are Underweight") elif (yourbmi >=18.5 and yourbmi <24.9):     print("your weight is normal") elif (yourbmi >=24.9 and yourbmi <=29.9):     print("you are overweight") elif (yourbmi >29.9 and yourbmi <34.9):     print ("you are obese") elif (yourbmi >=34.9 and yourbmi <39.9):     print ("you are severely obese") else :     print ("you are morbidly obese")

author: @paullemaron5258
text: Here is mine #Simple BMI calculator name = input("Enter your name: ") mass = int(input("Enter your weight in kg: ")) height = float(input("Enter your height in metres: ")) BMI = mass /(height**2) print(name,"Your BMI is:", BMI) if BMI < 18.5:     print(name, "You are underweight") elif BMI <= 24.9:     print(name, "You are Normal weight") elif BMI <= 29.9:     print(name, "You are Overweight") elif BMI >= 30:     print(name, "You are Obese") else:     print("Invalid Input")

author: @fede77
text: Hi Alex! Great course! Learning a lot!  Thanks! I know this tutorial for beginners, but anyway I'd like to comment that there's a better approach to the if-elif-elif-elif code (commonly known as arrow anti-pattern) in this case. Having a reference table as the source for the logic allows possible future changes (e.g. if the IBM values change for some reason) WITHOUT having to change the logic of the code, only the data contained in the table would be modified in that case.  Something like this:  ref_table = [ {   0.0 : "a feather" },               {  18.5 : "underweight" },                {  24.9 : "normal weight" },               {  29.9 : "overweight" },               {  39.4 : "obese" },               {  39.9 : "severely obeese" },               {  99.9 : "morbidly obese" },               { 999.9 : "life-threatening obese" }             ]  name   = input("Enter your name: ") weight = int(input("Enter your weight in pounds: ")) height = int(input("Enter your height in inches: ")) BMI = (weight * 703) / (height * height)  for pos in range(len(ref_table)):     if ( BMI >= list(ref_table[pos].keys())[0] and BMI < list(ref_table[pos+1].keys())[0] ):         print(name +  ", your BMI is " + str(int(BMI)) + ". You are " + list(ref_table[pos+1].values())[0])

author: @JenniferHawes
text: I used some while statements in my code to check for valid inputs. 😊  def find_bmi():     while True:         name = input("Name:")         if name.isalpha():             break         else:             print("Only use letters for your name please.")     while True:         weight = input("Weight(lbs): ")         if weight.isnumeric():             break         else:             print("Please input numbers only.")     while True:         height = input("Height(in): ")         if height.isnumeric():             break         else:             print("Please input numbers only.")     BMI = round((int(weight) * 703)/pow(int(height), 2), 1)     if(BMI < 16):         print(name + " your BMI = " + str(BMI) + ". You are severly underweight -- High Health Risk")     elif(16 < BMI < 18.5):         print(name + " your BMI = " + str(BMI) + ". You are underweight -- Minimal Health Risk")     elif(18.5 <= BMI < 25):         print(name + " your BMI = " + str(BMI) + ". You are normal weight -- Minimal Health Risk")     elif(25 <= BMI < 30):         print(name + " your BMI = " + str(BMI) + ". You are overweight -- Increased Health Risk")     elif(30 <= BMI < 35):         print(name + " your BMI = " + str(BMI) + ". You are obese -- High Health Risk")     elif(35 <= BMI < 40):         print(name + " your BMI = " + str(BMI) + ". You are severely Obese -- Very High Health Risk")     else:         print(name + " your BMI = " + str(BMI) + ". You are morbidly Obese -- Extremely High Health Risk")          find_bmi()

author: @user-yl1go5yd2c
text: Side note for anyone who entered their height and weight and is panicking, the American Medical Association doesn't recommend using BMI alone to measure fat mass or as an indicator of health. Some olympic athletes technically would be evaluated as "overweight" because a pound of muscle and a pound of fat weigh the same.

author: @sdlfjlsdirnsfsi232qrlfn
text: def bmi_category(bmi):   if bmi < 18.5:     return "Underweight"   elif bmi < 24.9:     return "Normal weight"   elif bmi < 29.9:     return "Overweight"   elif bmi < 34.9:     return "Obese"   elif bmi < 39.9:     return "Severely obese"   else:     return "Morbidly obese"   weight = float(input('Enter your weight in kgs: ')) height = int(input('Enter your height in cms: ')) height_in_meters = height / 100 BMI = weight / height_in_meters**2  bmi_category_name = bmi_category(BMI)  if BMI > 0:   print(f"Your BMI is {BMI:.2f}. You are {bmi_category_name}.") else:   print(f"Invalid input try agian")

author: @srdivz5
text: Correction with the above code: All of the end limits should be less than or equal to just like the first one done by Alex. Otherwise, if the weight just has less than 29.9, it gets categorized under the wrong weight range.  if BMI>0:     if BMI<18.5:         print(name,', you are Underweight')     elif BMI<=24.9:         print(name,', you are Normal Weight!')     elif BMI<=29.9:         print(name,', you are Overweight')     elif BMI<=34.9:         print(name,', you are Obese')     elif (BMI<=39.9):         print(name,", you are severely obese.")     else:         print(name,", you are morbidly obese.") else:     print("Enter valid input")
